awd_titl_txt: Computational Study of Symmetry-Driven Isotope Effect and Oxygen Mass-Independent Fractionation (O-MIF)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is to improve understanding of the fundamental details for the reaction forming ozone from a combination of molecular oxygen and atomic oxygen and how it effects the distribution of heavy isotopes of oxygen (17O and 18O). The rate and distribution of products in this reaction impact ozone's chemistry, production, lifetime and loss in the atmosphere, and the effect ozone has on global climate change. 

The team will calculate the influence of the Coriolis effect on energies and lifetimes of symmetric and asymmetric ozone molecules and to predict the energies of quantized rotational vibrational states in symmetric and asymmetric ozone molecules. Finally, this theory will be applied to isotope effects in other similar molecules. These calculations and insight into the isotopic distribution or the mass-independent fractionation (MIF) will be used to understand chemical processes occurring in the ancient atmosphere on Earth and other planets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recombination reaction that forms ozone in Earth's atmosphere

O + O2 (+ bath gas) => O3 

keeps puzzling atmospheric chemists and physical chemists for several decades. In particular, it is still not entirely clear why the isotopically substituted asymmetric ozone molecules, such as 16O16O18O and 16O16O17O, form faster by ~ 20% than symmetric ozone molecules. Importantly, this well-documented property, named eta-effect, depends neither on mass, nor on the number of oxygen isotopes in O3, and therefore is directly responsible for mass-independent fractionation of oxygen isotopes observed in the atmosphere of Earth and in many laboratory experiments. Namely, the same ~ 20% difference is found for the rates of formation of symmetric and asymmetric ozone molecules with single, double and triple substitutions of rare isotopes 17O or 18O.

In this project the computational chemistry team of Prof. Babikov at Marquette University has developed a quantum-mechanical theory to describe the rotational and vibrational motion of isotopically substituted ozone molecules. This theory was implemented in a custom computer program that calculates the properties of rotational-vibrational states of ozone below and above reaction threshold, which is a key element needed to model the process of its formation, and hopefully to understand the origin of the mysterious eta-effect in O3. The program is general and can be employed for similar calculations on other triatomic molecules, such as SiO2, CO2 and N2O, where some unusual isotope fractionations were either observed or predicted. The code takes full advantage of the massive parallelization offered by today’s supercomputers. It was made available to the scientific community through MarquetteQuantum/SpectrumSDT (github.com). Using this computer program, the team has created a unique database of rotational-vibrational states in all relevant ozone molecules, symmetric and asymmetric, with single and double substitutions of 17O or 18O isotopes. This database is made available to the community through MarquetteQuantum/OZONEData (github.com). Now this database is used by the students in Prof. Babikov's group to carry out a very detailed modelling of the recombination process that forms ozone molecules at different values of temperature and pressure, to finally understand why the isotopically substituted asymmetric ozone molecules are produced faster.

Fractionations of stable isotopes are used by geoscientists as a powerful source of information on chemical processes in the early Solar system, in the ancient atmosphere of Earth and in the atmospheres of other planets. In particular, the mass-independent fractionation of O3 has a significant impact on our understanding of ozone’s chemistry, production, lifetime and loss in the atmosphere, and of the influence of ozone on global climate change. Similar isotope fractionations are found in atmospheric CO2, N2O, CO and H2O2, and in sulfur-reach Archean deposits. During this project the team has published 11 articles in peer-reviewed journals, gave 8 invited or contributed talks, and presented 8 posters at various scientific meetings. Two PhD dissertations and one MS thesis on the topic of the project were defended by graduate students. Two more graduate students participated in the project and are now on their way to a PhD degree.
